American Water’s board of directors is committed to fostering a culture of integrity, accountability and respect at all levels of the organization and with all stakeholders.

Our directors are committed to ensuring that American Water is adhering to building a corporate governance infrastructure that provides transparency and delivers value for our shareholders, our customers, employees, and business partners.
Political Process & Procedure:
- Size: Subject to the Bylaws, the Board shall establish the number of Directors to serve on the Board upon the Nominating/Corporate Governance Committee’s recommendation. 
 
- Term Limits: None.

 - Election Schedule: The Board identifies, evaluates and selects candidates for the Board. The Nominating/Corporate Governance Committee is responsible for reviewing the qualifications of potential candidates and making recommendations to the whole Board regarding candidates for election to the Board at the Company’s annual meeting of shareholders and for candidates to fill vacancies on the Board that may occur between annual meetings of shareholders.

 - Review Process: The Nominating/Corporate Governance
Committee is also responsible for reviewing with the Board, on an annual basis, the appropriate skills and characteristics required of Board members in the context of the current make-up of the Board, the Company’s strategy and current business environment in which it operates.

 - Director Independence: A substantial majority of the Board is made up of independent directors. To be considered an “independent director,” a director must meet the New York Stock Exchange (“NYSE”) standards of independence, as determined by the Board.
Candidate Criteria: Nominees for Director shall be selected on the basis of their character, expertise, sound judgment, ability to make independent analytical inquiries, business experiences, understanding of the Company’s business environment, ability to make time commitments to the Company, demonstrated teamwork, and ability to bring unique and diverse perspectives and understandings to the Board.

- Size: Under the Bylaws, the size of the Board ranges between seven and eleven, as determined by the Board of Directors.  Currently, the Board has eleven members.  
 
- Term Limits: None. A Director must retire no later than the Annual Meeting following their 75th birthday.

 - Election Schedule: Directors of the Company are elected by stockholders for a one-year term. The Nominating/Corporate Governance Committee reviews the qualifications of director candidates and recommends the Company’s candidates to the Board for election by the stockholders at the Annual Meeting.

 - Review Process: The Nominating/Corporate Governance Committee considers and makes recommendations to the Board regarding the size, structure, composition and functioning of the Board. There is an annual evaluation of the Board’s composition to enable the Board and the Nominating/Corporate Governance Committee to assess the skills and experience that are currently represented on the Board as a whole, and in individual directors, and to update these skills and experience as necessary in light of the Company’s anticipated needs, including its current and future business and operations.

 - Director Independence: A substantial majority of the Board is made up of independent directors. To be considered an “independent director,” a director must meet the New York Stock Exchange (“NYSE”) standards of independence, as determined by the Board.
Candidate Criteria:
The Board’s consider a candidtate as qualified against the following criteria:
 -  leadership in a particular field
 -  broad experience and sound business judgment
 - expertise in areas of importance to the Company
 - ability to work in a collegial board environment
 - the highest personal and professional ethics and integrity
 - ability to devote required time to carrying out director responsibilities
 - ability and willingness to contribute special competencies to Board and committee activities
 - freedom from conflicts of interest that would interfere with serving and acting in the best interests of the Company and its stockholders
 - achievement of prominence in a career
